=== Education ===
The third [[Millennium Development Goal]] is directed at achieving [[gender equality]] and women’s empowerment around the world.<ref>http://www.un.org/millenniumgoals/gender.shtml</ref> Improvement of equal educational opportunity contributes to the women’s empowerment<ref>Salome Francis, 1991, "Empower the Women! Empower the Nation", Sexual Politics, pp. 33-35</ref> Women have traditionally had limited access to higher education.<ref>Solomon, Barbara Miller. ''In the Company of Educated Women.''</ref> When women ''were'' admitted to higher education, they were encouraged to major in less-intellectual subjects; the study of [[English literature]] in American and British colleges and universities was instituted as a field considered suitable to women's "lesser intellects".<ref>Eagleton, Terry. ''Literary Theory.''</ref>
Educational specialties in higher education produce and perpetuate the existing segregation between men and women. Disparity persists particularly in computer and [[information science]], where women receive only 21 percent of the undergraduate degrees, and in [[engineering]], women obtain only 19 percent of the degrees in 2008.<ref>Fox, M. Sonnert G. and Nikiforova, I., 2011, Programs for Undergraduate Women in Science and Engineering: Issues, Problems, and Solutions, Gender and Society, 25 vol., p. 590</ref>
World literacy is lower for females than for males. Latest data from CIA World Factbook shows that 79.7% of women are literate, compared to 88.6% of men (aged 15 and over).<ref>https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html</ref> In some parts of the world, girls continue to be excluded from proper public or private education. In parts of [[Afghanistan]], girls who go to school face serious violence from some local community members and religious groups.<ref name="edition.cnn.com">{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/08/02/world/meast/cnnheroes-jan-afghan-school/index.html | work=CNN | title=Acid attacks, poison: What Afghan girls risk by going to school - CNN.com | date=August 2, 2012}}</ref><ref name="edition.cnn.com"/> According to 2010 UN estimates, only [[Afghanistan]], [[Pakistan]] and [[Yemen]] had less than 90 girls per 100 boys at school.<ref>"Making Room for Girls" (2013), Retrieved from http://www.economist.com/blogs/freeexchange/2013/11/gender-inequality.</ref> Greater variation of gender educational discrepancy exists within countries. The situation appears to be more critical in rural areas, for instance [[UNICEF]] statistics revealed that in Nigerian villages less than 40 girls per 100 boys gained access to primary education.<ref>http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/nigeria_statistics.html</ref> Studies of [[Sri Lanka]] economic development suggested that increased life expectancy of girls encourages educational investment because a longer time horizon increases the value of investments that pay out over time.<ref>JAYACHANDRAN S. AND LLERAS-MUNEY A., 2009, Life expectancy and human capital investments: evidence from material mortality declines, available at http://qje.oxfordjournals.org/</ref>
Girls' educational opportunities and results have greatly improved in the West. Since 1991, the proportion of women enrolled in college in the United States has exceeded the enrollment rate for men; the gap has widened over time.<ref>National Center for Education Statistics, http://nces.ed.gov/pubs2005/2005028.pdf</ref> As of 2007, women made up the majority—54 percent—of the 10.8 million college students enrolled in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prb.org/Articles/2007/CrossoverinFemaleMaleCollegeEnrollmentRates.aspx |title=The Crossover in Female-Male College Enrollment Rates |publisher=Prb.org |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref>
Research has found that discrimination continues; boys receive more attention, praise, blame and punishment in the grammar-school classroom,<ref>Halpern, Diane F. ''Sex differences in cognitive abilities.'' Laurence Erlbaum Associates, 2000. ISBN 0-8058-2792-7. Page 259.</ref> and "this pattern of more active teacher attention directed at male students continues at the postsecondary level".<ref>Sadker, Myra, and David Sadker. "Confronting Sexism in the College Classroom." In ''Gender in the Classroom: Power and Pedagogy.'' Ed. Susan L. Gabriel and Isaiah Smithson. Page 177.</ref> Over time, female students speak less in a classroom setting.<ref>Sadker, Myra, and David Sadker. "Failing at Fairness: Hidden Lessons." In ''Mapping the social landscape: readings in sociology.'' Ed. Sandra J. Ferguson, [[Susan J. Ferguson]]. Taylor & Francies, 1999. ISBN 0-7674-0616-8. Page 350.</ref>
It is also argued that the educational system has become "feminized", allowing girls more of a chance at success with a more "girl-friendly" environment in the classroom;<ref>{{cite web|first=Gerry |last=Garibaldi |url=http://www.city-journal.org/html/16_3_schools_boys.html |title=How the Schools Shortchange Boys |publisher=City-journal.org |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> this is seen to hinder boys by punishing "masculine" behaviour and diagnosing boys with [[Emotional and behavioral disorders|behavioural disorders]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Carolyn |last=Abraham |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/time-to-lead/failing-boys/part-3-are-we-medicating-a-disorder-or-treating-boyhood-as-a-disease/article1762859/ |title=Part 3: Are we medicating a disorder or treating boyhood as a disease? |publisher=The Globe and Mail |accessdate=July 20, 2013 |location=Toronto |date=August 23, 2012}}</ref>
In 2011 a [[United States Bureau of Labor Statistics]] report found that women are more likely than men to earn a [[bachelor's degree]] by age 23.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/10/post_644_n_821577.html |title=More Women Earn Bachelor's Degrees Than Men, Study Shows |publisher=Huffington Post |accessdate=July 20, 2013 |first=Danielle |last=Wienerbronner |date=February 10, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bls.gov/ |title=U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics |publisher=Bls.gov |date=July 16, 2013 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> A survey conducted by the [[Council of Graduate Schools]] similarly found that in the 2008–09 school year, women earned 50.9% of [[doctorate]]s and 60% of [[master's degrees]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/20/education/20iht-educBriefs20.html?_r=0 | work=The New York Times | title=Women Earning More Doctoral Degrees Than Men in U.S | date=September 19, 2010}}</ref> However, only one-fifth of [[physics]] Ph.D.’s in the [[US]] are awarded to women, and only about half of those women are American; of all the physics professors in the country, only 14 percent are women.<ref>Why Are There Still So Few Women in Science? Retrieved from http://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/06/magazine/why-are-there-still-so-few-women-in-science.html?_r=1&</ref>
There is a clear evidence that education plays an important role in determining women's input in financial and household decisions related to social and organizational matters.<ref>Anju Malhotra and Mark Mather, 1997, Do Schooling and Work Empower Women in Developing Countries? Sociological Forum, Vol. 12, No. 4, pp. 599-630</ref>
Girls earn higher grades than boys until the end of high school; in some districts, girls achieve higher marks despite similar (or lower) scores than boys on standardised tests.<ref>Public Policy Sources, http://www.fraserinstitute.org/commerce.web/product_files/BoysGirlsandGradesIntro.pdf</ref>
=== Fashion === {{See also|Foot binding|Burqa}} Feminists argue that some fashion trends have been oppressive to women; they restrict women's movements, increase their vulnerability and endanger their health.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jeffreys|first1=Sheila|title=Beauty and Misogyny:Harmful cultural practices in the west|url=http://www.feministes-radicales.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Jeffreys_Beauty_and_Misogyny_Harmful_Cultural_Practices_in_the_West__Women_and_Psychology_1.pdf|accessdate=March 8, 2013|year=2005|publisher=Taylor & Francis e-Library|location=East Sussex|isbn=0-203-69856-8}}</ref> The fashion industry is dealing with a great deal of criticism, as their association of thin-models and beauty has said to encourage [[bulimia]] and [[anorexia nervosa]] within women, as well as locking female consumers into false feminine identities.<ref>{{cite book |last=Hollows|first=Joanne|title=Feminism, Femininity and Popular Culture|url=http://books.google.com/?id=sXWjnG5LWO0C&lpg=PA139&dq=Oppressive%20fashions%20feminism&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q=Oppressive%20fashions%20feminism&f=false |accessdate=March 11, 2013|year=2000|publisher=Manchester University Press|location=Manchester, UK|isbn=0-7190-4394-8|page=139}}</ref>
The assigning of gender specific baby clothes from young ages is seen as sexist by some as it can instil in children from young ages a belief in strong gender stereotypes.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/julie-bindel-boys-arent-born-wanting-to-wear-blue-6293688.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Julie | last=Bindel | title=Julie Bindel: Boys aren't born wanting to wear blue | date=January 24, 2012}}</ref> An example of this is the assignment in some countries of the color [[pink]] to girls and [[blue]] to boys. This fashion, however, is a recent one; at the beginning of the 20th century the trend was the opposite: blue for girls and pink for boys. In the early 1900s, The Women's Journal wrote: "That pink being a more decided and stronger colour, is more suitable for the boy, while blue, which is more delicate and dainty, is prettier for the girl." ''DressMaker'' magazine also explained: "The preferred colour to dress young boys in is pink. Blue is reserved for girls as it is considered paler, and the more dainty of the two colours, and pink is thought to be stronger (akin to red)."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/7817496.stm | work=BBC News | title=Should we not dress girls in pink? | date=January 8, 2009}}</ref> [[File:LouisXVchild.jpg|thumb|150 px|right|[[Louis XV]] in 1712, as a boy, wearing a pink dress]] [[File:Rwandan school children.jpg|thumb|150 px|left|Children in [[Rwanda]]. Notice how all children, regardless of sex, have very short hair (these children are wearing their school uniforms: girls are in skirts and boys in shorts)]]
Today, in most countries of the world, it is considered inappropriate for boys to wear dresses and skirts, but this, again, is a modern worldview: for example, from the mid-16th century<ref>Melanie Scheussler suggests a date of post-1540 for England, France, and the Low Countries; see Scheussler, "'She Hath Over Grown All that She Ever Hath': Children's Clothing in the Lisle Letters, 1533-40", in Netherton, Robin, and Gale R. Owen-Crocker, editors, ''Medieval Clothing and Textiles'', Volume 3, p. 185. Before roughly this date various styles of long robes were in any case commonly worn by adult males of various sorts, so boys wearing them could probably not be said to form a distinct phenomenon.</ref> until the late 19th or early 20th century, young boys in the [[Western world]] were [[Breeches|unbreeched]] and wore [[gown]]s or [[dress]]es until an age that varied between two and eight.<ref>Baumgarten, Linda: ''What Clothes Reveal: The Language of Clothing in Colonial and Federal America'', p. 166</ref> Also, throughout much of the history, in most cultures, men have worn skirt-like clothes and worn long hair. In many parts of the world, such as much of sub-Saharan Africa, it is considered normal for women to wear very short hair, with the hairstyles of boys being the same to those of girls.
=== Female infanticide and sex-selective abortion === {{Main|Sex-selective abortion|Missing women of Asia}} [[File:Something you wouldn't see in America.jpg|thumb| Female infanticide is still a major problem in India.]] [[Female infanticide]] is the killing of very young female children. It is an extreme form of [[gender based violence]].<ref name="eige.europa.eu">http://eige.europa.eu/content/what-is-gender-based-violence</ref><ref name="ReferenceB">http://www.bbc.co.uk/ethics/abortion/medical/infanticide_1.shtml</ref><ref>http://www.gsdrc.org/go/topic-guides/gender/gender-based-violence</ref> Female infanticide is more common than male infanticide, and is especially prevalent in parts of [[Asia]], such as parts of [[India]] and [[People's Republic of China|China]].<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6934540.stm | work=BBC News | first=Nick | last=Bryant | title=Girls at risk amid India's prosperity | date=August 18, 2007}}</ref><ref>http://www.domesticviolenceservices.com/female-infanticide.htm</ref> Recent studies suggest that over 90 million [[Missing women of Asia|girls and women are missing]] in China and India as a result of systematic sex discrimination.<ref>"[http://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/24/opinion/24iht-edswami.html?_r=0 Missing: 50 million Indian girls]". The New York Times. November 25, 2005</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://iussp2005.princeton.edu/download.aspx?submissionId=51345 |title=Estimation of the Number of Missing Females in China: 1900-2000 |accessdate=2013-07-18}}</ref>
Sex-selective abortion involves terminating a pregnancy based upon the predicted gender of the baby. The [[abortion]] of female fetuses is most common in areas where the culture values male children over females,<ref name="Goodkind">{{cite journal |author=Goodkind, Daniel |year=1999 |title=Should Prenatal Sex Selection be Restricted?: Ethical Questions and Their Implications for Research and Policy |journal=Population Studies |volume=53 |issue=1 |pages=49–61 |jstor=2584811 |doi=10.1080/00324720308069}}</ref> such as parts of the [[People's Republic of China]], [[India]], [[Pakistan]], [[Korea]], [[Taiwan]], and the [[Caucasus]].<ref name="Goodkind"/><ref name="Gettis">A. Gettis, J. Getis, and J. D. Fellmann (2004). Introduction to Geography, Ninth Edition. New York: McGraw-Hill. pp. 200. ISBN 0-07-252183-X</ref> One reason for this preference is that males are seen as generating more income than females. A 2011 report on ''[[Science Daily]]'' stated that the trend grew steadily during the previous decade, and would probably cause a future shortage of women.<ref>Canadian Medical Association Journal (2011, March 14). The impact of sex selection and abortion in China, India and South Korea. ScienceDaily. Retrieved March 26, 2012, from http://www.sciencedaily.com /releases/2011/03/110314132244.ht</ref>
===Forced sterilization and forced abortion=== [[Forced sterilization]] and [[forced abortion]] are forms of gender-based violence.<ref name="eige.europa.eu"/>
Forced sterilization was practiced during the first half of the 20th century by many Western countries (including the US) and there are reports of this practice being currently employed in some countries, such as [[Uzbekistan]] and [[People's Republic of China|China]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-17612550 | work=BBC News | title=Uzbekistan's policy of secretly sterilising women | date=April 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01fjx63</ref><ref>http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/asia-pacific/china/130409/china-mother-dies-after-forced-sterilization-one-child-policy</ref><ref>http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/thousands-risk-forced-sterilization-china-2010-04-22</ref>
Forced abortions are today associated mostly with China. Although they are not an official policy of the country, they result from government pressure on local officials who, in turn, employ strong-arm tactics on pregnant mothers. In 2012, a highy publicized case of a forced abortion involving the photo of the fetus has sparked international outrage.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-18435126 | work=BBC News | title=China forced abortion photo sparks outrage | date=June 14, 2012}}</ref>
===Female genital mutilation=== {{Main|Female genital mutilation}} [[File:Campaign road sign against female genital mutilation (cropped).jpg|270px|thumb|Campaign against [[female genital mutilation]] in [[Uganda]].]] [[Female genital mutilation]] (FGM), also known as female genital cutting and female circumcision, is defined by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) as "all procedures that involve partial or total removal of the external female genitalia, or other injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons". WHO states that, "The procedure has no health benefits for girls and women" and "Procedures can cause severe bleeding and problems urinating, and later cysts, infections, infertility as well as complications in childbirth increased risk of newborn death"<ref name="WHO">http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs241/en/</ref> and "FGM is recognized internationally as a violation of the human rights of girls and women. It reflects deep-rooted [[gender inequality|inequality between the sexes]], and constitutes an extreme form of [[gender discrimination|discrimination against women]]".<ref name="WHO" /> Feminist activist Seham Abd el Salam writes that FGM campaigners have been criticized by [[women's studies]] groups for their lack of recognition of male circumcision as a form of genital mutilation.<ref>{{cite journal|last=El-Salam|first=Seham Abd|title=The Importance of Genital Mutilations to Gender Power Politics|journal=[[Al-Raida]]|year=2002/2003|volume=20|issue=99|page=42|publisher=Institute for Women’s Studies in the Arab World|quote=Women’s defense of men's right to bodily integrity and their work against MGM will not have a negative impact on their struggle against FGM.}}</ref>
According to a 2013 UNICEF report, 125 million women and girls in Africa and the Middle East have experienced FGM.<ref name="ReferenceA">http://www.unicef.org/media/files/FGCM_Lo_res.pdf</ref> The highest prevalence in Africa is documented in [[Somalia]] (98 percent of women affected), [[Guinea]] (96 percent), [[Djibouti]] (93 percent), Egypt (91 percent), Eritrea (89 percent), Mali (89 percent), Sierra Leone (88 percent), Sudan (88 percent), Gambia (76 percent), Burkina Faso (76 percent), Ethiopia (74 percent), Mauritania (69 percent), Liberia (66 percent), and Guinea-Bissau (50 percent).<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
=== Hate-motivated sexual assault === Rape and sexual assault are considered to be acts of hate. Their relationship to sexism is the frequent desire on the part of the perpetrator for power over the victim. The Center for Women Policy Studies stated that "victims almost always are chosen for what they are rather than who they are"; a woman is more likely to be attacked because of her gender than her individuality.<ref>The National Center for Victims of Crime</ref>
Research into factors motivating perpetrators of [[rape]] against women frequently reveals a pattern of hatred towards women and pleasure in inflicting psychological and physical trauma, rather than sexual interest.<ref name=Lisak1988>{{cite journal | author = Lisak, D. |authorlink=David Lisak |author2=Roth, S. | year = 1988 | title = Motivational factors in nonincarcerated sexually aggressive men | journal = J Pers Soc Psychol | volume = 55 | issue = 5 | pages = 795–802 | pmid = 3210146 | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.55.5.795}}</ref> Mary Odem posits that rape is the result not of pathology but of systems of male dominance, cultural practices and beliefs which objectify and degrade women.<ref name=Odem>{{Cite book | author=Odem, Mary E.; |author2=Clay-Warner, Jody | title=Confronting rape and sexual assault | year=1998 | publisher=Scholarly Resources | location=Wilmington, Del. | isbn=978-0-8420-2599-7 | pages=i-x}}</ref>
[[File:Bangalore protests following Delhi gang-rape (photo - Jim Ankan Deka).jpg|thumb|People in [[Bangalore]], [[India]] demanding justice for young student who was [[2012 Delhi gang rape case|gang-raped in Delhi]] in December 2012]] Mary Odem, Jody Clay-Warner and [[Susan Brownmiller]] consider that sexist attitudes are propagated by a series of myths about rape and rapists.<ref name="Odem" />{{rp|130–140}} <ref name=Brownmiller>{{Cite book | author=Brownmiller, Susan | title=Against Our Will: Men, Women and Rape | year=1992 | publisher=Penguin Books, Limited | location=New York | isbn=978-0-14-013986-0 | page=480}}</ref> They state that in contrast to those myths, rapists often plan a rape before they choose a victim<ref name="Odem"/> and [[acquaintance rape]] (not assault by a stranger) is the most common form of rape.<ref name="Odem" />{{rp|xiv}}<ref name=Bohmer>{{Cite book | editor=Parrot, Andrea; Bechhofer, Laurie | author=Bohmer, Carol | chapter=Acquaintance rape and the law | title=Acquaintance rape: the hidden crime | year=1991 | publisher=Wiley | location=New York | isbn=978-0-471-51023-9 | pages=317–333}}</ref> Odem also asserts that these rape myths propagate sexist attitudes about men, by perpetuating the belief that men cannot control their sexuality.<ref name=Odem>{{Cite book | author=Odem, Mary E.; |author2=Clay-Warner, Jody | title=Confronting rape and sexual assault | year=1998 | publisher=Scholarly Resources | location=Wilmington, Del. | isbn=978-0-8420-2599-7 | page=135}}</ref>
In response to [[acquaintance rape]], the "Men Can Stop Rape" movement has been implemented.<ref>http://www.mencanstoprape.org/</ref> The U.S. military has begun a similar movement, with the slogan "My strength is for defending".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov/releases/release.aspx?releaseid=13379 |title=News Release: DOD Releases Annual Sexual Assault Response and Prevention Report |publisher=Defense.gov |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref>
In ''Yes Means Yes: Visions of Female Sexual Power and A World Without Rape'' by [[Jaclyn Friedman]] and [[Jessica Valenti]], it is argued that in the US rape is most often popularly depicted (in the media, in public discourse, in movies etc.) as stranger-rape (with a stereotypical stranger who "jumps out of the bushes"), despite the fact that most rapes do not fit this stereotype. In presenting rape in this way to the public, patriarchal society ensures that women are kept under control, at home/indoors, living their life according to traditional gender roles and expectations, dressed 'modestly'. This leads to an ideology that women are safe at home (ignoring rape by family members/partners), and to [[victim blaming|blaming of victims]].<ref>http://books.google.ro/books?id=NyicMIxzkUwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Yes+Means+Yes:&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YW48UpOlH8KGtAb8p4CQCQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Yes%20Means%20Yes%3A&f=false</ref>
=== Military service === {{see also|Military service|Israel#Military|l2=Israeli military}} Military service has been considered a gender-specific duty. Some countries, such as [[Israel]], require military service regardless of gender. Others (such as [[Conscription in Finland|Finland]], [[Conscription in Turkey|Turkey]] and [[Conscription in Singapore|Singapore]]) still use a system of [[conscription]] which only requires military service for men, although women are permitted to serve voluntarily.
In the United States, all men must register with the [[Selective Service System]] within 30 days of their 18th birthday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sss.gov/default.htm |title=Selective Service System: Welcome |publisher=Sss.gov |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> The system does not require women to register, leading to criticism that it discriminates against men by forcing them into a dangerous role based on gender.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://haergar06.wordpress.com/2008/01/19/selective-service-is-one-the-worst-and-most-sexist-discriminations-against-men/ |title=Selective Service is one of the Worst And Most Sexist Discriminations against Men | The Marketplace of Ideas |publisher=Haergar06.wordpress.com |date=January 19, 2008 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref>
=== Misandry === {{Main|Misandry}} Misandry is the hatred of men and boys as a societal group or as individuals.
=== Misogyny === {{Main|Misogyny}} Misogyny is the hatred of women and girls as a societal group or as individuals.
=== Sexual slavery === [[Image:Chinese girl from one of the Japanese Army's 'comfort battalions'.jpg|thumb|[[Rangoon]], [[Burma]]. August 8, 1945. A young [[Chinese diaspora|ethnic Chinese]] woman who was in one of the [[Imperial Japanese Army]]'s "comfort battalions" is interviewed by an [[Royal Air force|RAF]] officer.]] {{Main|Sexual slavery}} Sexual slavery occurs when people are coerced into [[slavery]] for [[Human sexual activity|sexual]] [[exploitation]]. The incidence of sexual slavery by country has been studied and tabulated by [[UNESCO]] (the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization) with the cooperation of a number of international agencies.<ref>http://www.unescobkk.org/fileadmin/user_upload/culture/Trafficking/project/Graph_Worldwide_Sept_2004.pdf</ref> Sexual slavery also includes single-owner slavery, the ritual slavery associated with certain religious practices, slavery for primarily non-sexual purposes where non-consensual [[sex]] is common and [[forced prostitution]].
=== Transphobia === {{Main|Transphobia}} {{See also|Phobia|l1=Phobia - terms for prejudice or discrimination}} Transphobia refers to prejudice against transsexuality and transsexual (or transgender) people based on their gender identification. Whether intentional or not, transphobia can have negative consequences for the object of the negative attitude. The lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender ([[LGBT]]) movement opposes sexism against transsexuals. One form of sexism against transsexuals is "women-only" and "men-only" events and organizations, which have been criticized for excluding trans women and trans men.<ref>"Michigan Women's Music Festival ends policy of discrimination against Transwomen" http://www.intraa.org/story/newmwmfpolicy</ref><ref>Lesfest. http://www.lesbian.com/news/international_2003_1006.html</ref>
=== Treatment of victims of rape === Stigmatization of women and girls who have been raped is widespread in many cultures; is a result of gender inequality and patriarchal social norms; and affects the ability of victims to recover.<ref name="whqlibdoc.who.int">http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2002/9241545615_chap6_eng.pdf?ua=1</ref><ref>http://www.svri.org/rape.pdf</ref> In many parts of the world, women who have been raped are ostracized, rejected by their families, subjected to violence - in extreme cases to [[honor killings]], because they are deemed to have brought 'shame' on their families.<ref name="whqlibdoc.who.int"/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13760895 | work=BBC News | title=Libya rape victims 'face honour killings' | date=June 14, 2011}}</ref>
There is also a strong connection between rape and [[forced marriage]], through practices such as forcing of a woman or girl who has been raped to marry her rapist, in order to restore the 'honor' of her family;<ref name="whqlibdoc.who.int"/><ref>http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-17379721</ref> or [[marriage by abduction]], a practice in which a man abducts the woman or girl whom he wishes to marry and rapes her, in order to force the marriage (this practice is very common in [[Ethiopia]]<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/371944.stm | work=BBC News | title=Ethiopia: Revenge of the abducted bride | date=June 18, 1999}}</ref><ref>http://www.irinnews.org/report/69993/ethiopia-surviving-forced-marriage</ref><ref>http://www.pathfinder.org/publications-tools/pdfs/Causes-and-Consequesnces-of-Early-Marriage-in-the-Amhara-Region-of-Ethiopia.pdf</ref>). The criminalization of [[marital rape]] (forcing one's own spouse to have sex) is very recent, having occurred during the past few decades; and in many countries it is still legal. Several countries in Eastern Europe and Scandinavia made spousal rape illegal before 1970; other countries in Western Europe and the English-speaking Western World outlawed it later, mostly in the 1980s and 1990s.<ref>http://books.google.ro/books?id=VWttAAAAQBAJ&pg=PR1&lpg=PR1&dq=The+Routledge+Handbook+of+European+Criminology&source=bl&ots=W397XfxDSQ&sig=KC-3iBJ6HPkmE5WUZP9vldrwQFA&hl=ro&sa=X&ei=WhTUUsLiM8GTywONt4CYCw&ved=0CEcQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=The%20Routledge%20Handbook%20of%20European%20Criminology&f=false</ref> In some parts of the world the lack of criminalization of marital rape coupled with the practice of child marriage leads to serious forms of [[child sexual abuse]] being legitimized. The WHO wrote that: "Marriage is often used to legitimize a range of forms of sexual violence against women. The custom of marrying off young children, particularly girls, is found in many parts of the world. This practice – legal in many countries – is a form of sexual violence, since the children involved are unable to give or withhold their consent".<ref name="whqlibdoc.who.int"/> (see above the section on Child Marriage).
In countries where [[fornication]] or [[adultery]] are illegal, victims of rape can be charged under this laws (even if the victims succeed in proving their rape case, they can still be charged with a criminal offense if the court finds they were not [[virgins]] at the time of the assault - if they were unmarried).<ref>http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-21595814</ref>
The WHO states that: "Persons who have been raped should receive treatment consistent with the dignity and respect they are owed as human beings."<ref>http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2004/924159263X.pdf?ua=1</ref>
=== War rape === {{Main|War rape}} [[File:DRC raped women.jpg|thumb|Meeting of victims of [[sexual violence]] in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.]] War rapes are [[rape]]s committed by soldiers, other combatants or civilians during armed conflict, [[war]] or military occupation, and are distinguished from in-service sexual assault and rape committed amongst troops.<ref>[http://theconservativeblog.co.uk/?p=2382 "30% of Women in USA Military Raped Whilst Serving by Fellow Soldiers"]</ref><ref>[http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=103844570 "The Nation: The Plight of Women Soldiers"]</ref><ref>[http://www.inthesetimes.com/article/3848/ "Why Soldiers Rape - Culture of misogyny, illegal occupation, fuel sexual violence in military"]</ref> It also encompasses situations in which women are forced into prostitution or [[sexual slavery]] by an occupying power, such as Japanese [[comfort women]] during World War II. Sexual violence and rape as a weapon of war also affects a large number of men, although it is less-often reported.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/society/2011/jul/17/the-rape-of-men|title=The rape of men|last1=Storr|first1=Will|date=16 July 2011|work=The Observer|accessdate=8 March 2013|location=London}}</ref> The war-torn [[Sexual violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Democratic Republic of the Congo]] has been described as the "rape capital of the world" with more than 400,000 rapes reported in just one year.<ref>"[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/400000-rapes-in-congo-in-one-year-2283102.html 400,000 rapes in Congo in one year]". ''[[The Independent]]''. May 12, 2011.</ref>
== Antisexism movements == {{See also|Women's rights|Men's rights}} In [[Ecuador]], the Pink Helmets (''Cascos Rosas''), created in May 2011 by 18-year-olds Freddy Caleron and Damian Valencia, sought to unite young men against [[machismo]].<ref>[http://www.saynotoviolence.org/join-say-no/ecuador-pink-helmets-say-no-violence-against-women Saynotoviolence.com].</ref> The Pink Helmets published a manual with suggestions to end violence in society, relationships, within families, and among friends. The Pink Helmets' founders and participating members, who call themselves ''neomasculinos'' and are 15–20 years old, visit schools and the streets to give talks and participate in festivals (such as the [[Quito Fest]]) in collaboration with [[UN Women]] (part of the United Nations) to increase awareness of violence and the movement against it.<ref>[http://www.unwomen.org/2011/11/espanol-los-jovenes-lideran-la-lucha-por-la-igualdad-y-contra-la-violencia-de-genero-en-ecuador/ UN Women].</ref> [[Chauvinism]] and violence are common in Ecuador, with 40% of children under age 15 saying that they have witnessed acts of violence at home.{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}} According to the ''National Plan for the Eradication of Gender Violence of the Government of Ecuador'', 80% of women have been victims of violence at least once and 21% of children and adolescents have been sexually abused<ref>[http://www.elmundo.es/america/2011/10/02/noticias/1317569157.html "Unos jóvenes combaten el machismo en Ecuador con cascos rosas"], ''El Mundo''.</ref> (no official data provide a concrete number of women who have been killed or injured by men). The movement aims to promote gender equality, eliminate gender violence against women and encourage a "dialogue of respect between men and women from adolescence without hesitation to criticize sexist concepts that live in their culture".<ref>[http://www.larepublica.pe/02-10-2011/ecuador-jovenes-combaten-el-machismo-con-cascos-rosas LaRepublica].</ref>
